sub_title: Early Stage Researcher | Co-Founder at Majicom
summary:
"Very motivated, charismatic, and eager to learn!”

I am a scientist, an engineer, and an educator with proficiencies in material science, physics and nanotechnology. I am currently working at TU Delft in the Netherlands, where I am probing quantum materials with a very sensitive sensor based on diamond.

I have educational and professional experiences in the Netherlands, Germany, France, Canada, Japan and the UK where I have proven my analytical skills working in diverse multidisciplinary teams. I am very confident in my ability to strongly contribute in any scientific or consulting environment due to my quick, imaginative, and strategic mind. 

I am open to collaboration and consulting opportunities. If you would like to discuss any opportunities, and how my experiences/skills may help you, please feel free to send me a message.

projects.title: Utilzing photoelectrochemistry and Raman spectroscopy to analyze 690 stainless steel
projects.description:
This project was worked on in a group of three along side two expert professors over two months as a component of the first year masters degree at Grenoble INP PHELMA in France.

The scope of the project involved:

1. Learning about Photo-electrochemistry and Raman spectroscopy as a characterization tool of electronic, optical, chemical properties of semiconducting compounds. Learning was done using TiO2 and SiC samples.

2. To use both tools allows to characterize 690 stainless steel samples to link the properties of the material with its specific fabrication process: high temperature oxidation, resistance in nuclear or petrochemical environments and so on.

projects.title: Superconducting Nanowire Single Photon Detector (SNSP)
projects.description:
This project served as a Capstone project of the undergraduate engineering BASc. degree at the University of Waterloo.

The project was completed in a team of five in a span of a year. It involved designing a versatile instrument that is capable of detecting light at low intensities which is useful in applications such as VLSI quality verification and live cell sampling and surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy, among others.

Project work included coding, circuit design, interfacing with SNSP, testing, and hardware/software integration. A grade of 92/100 was received on the project which involved a final presentation, poster preparation and technical report.

Associate Professor at University of Tennessee

profile_positions.description:
TU Delft is the largest and oldest Dutch technology University. TU Delft has been coined the Future Quantum Capital of Europe as it houses several Quantum institutes like the Microsoft Quantum Lab and the QuTech Institute which is a collaboration between both academia and industry to drive innovations in Quantum computing and Quantum internet. It also houses The Kavli Institute of Nanoscience which supports both bio and quantum nanoscience and provides world-class research facilities. 

I am currently working at the Kavli Institute of Nanoscience where I am engaging in state-of-the-art research using a very sensitive quantum sensor to probe a new class of materials with the potential to realize next-generation information technology that are more energy efficient.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

profile_positions.description: Majicom is a social enterprise with a dedicated mission of developing solar water purification solutions for water stressed areas in developing countries.
profile_positions.title: Co-Founder

profile_positions.description:
Kalamna (meaning ‘our words’ in Arabic) is a social enterprise that is transforming Arabic language learning. They make Arabic learning engaging and fun and focus on every day, conversational Arabic, enabling them to positively connect with children with their Arabic heritage.

I am a NED at Kalmana and I focus on directing their long-term growth and impact.
profile_positions.title: Non Executive Board Member

profile_positions.description:
I completed my PhD in Materials Science and Metallurgy in the Device Materials group at the University of Cambridge.

In my research, I focused on addressing capacity limits in conventional silicon-based data storage devices, due to restrictions on further miniaturization. I fabricated novel materials that have increased insensitivity, which is crucial to make “invisible” memories for encryption and safe data storage to meet demands in current information technologies. Furthermore, I use a sustainable materials selection approach to limit the use of noble metals, rare earth metals and other environmentally damaging materials, and to provide a long-lasting approach to information storage.
profile_positions.title: Early Stage Researcher

profile_positions.description: Shaping Horizons 2019 is a summit brings together top representatives and young leaders from policy, academia and industry from the UK and Latin America. The summit will discuss solutions to the most pressing bilateral challenges while breaking geographical, disciplinary and generational barriers. Shaping Horizons is a non-profit initiative backed by the University of Cambridge, which is being organised by the Cambridge Hub of the Global Shapers Community, a World Economic Forum initiative, as well as students, academics and staff from the University of Cambridge.
profile_positions.title: Co-director Social Challenges

profile_positions.description:
The National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) in Japan is a world-class research institute in Tsukuba (Japan). I was hosted at the Research Center for Magnetic and Spintronic Materials for three months to engage in cutting-edge research.

I was granted the NIMS award to conduct research focusing on thin films for efficient and densely integrated data storage technologies, using sustainable materials with low environmental impact.
profile_positions.title: Spintronics Research Visit

company.name: CEA - Commissariat à l'énergie atomique et aux énergies alternatives

profile_positions.description:
The CEA is a prominent European technology developing organization and is involved in setting up collaborative projects all around the world. As a project manager, I worked at the Center of Innovation for New Energy Technologies, where I coordinated all aspects of my master degree project, including: experiments, strategic planning, and equipment installations.

The project scope included innovating, designing and scaling up an inorganic electrolyte material to address Li-ion rechargeable battery safety issues with liquid organic electrolyte. It's success will help revolutionize the implementation of Li-ion batteries, specifically in electric vehicles. I was able to successfully develop a synthesis process of the material, saving over 200 hours in the process and wrote a 100 page thorough technical report analyzing and rationalizing data to detail the improvements.

To process the material I used ball-milling, calcination/heat-treatments, sintering, SPS, PVD. To collect data I used XRD, SEM/EDX, impedance spectroscopy, ICP, TGA DSC, and to process the data I utilized Origin Pro, Mathcad, and a Microsoft Excel macro program.
profile_positions.title: Project Manager - Engineering Masters Degree Industrial Thesis

company.name: Institute of Integrated Electronic Systems, TU Darmstadt

profile_positions.company: Institute of Integrated Electronic Systems, TU Darmstadt
profile_positions.description:
Technische Universität Darmstadt (Technical University of Darmstadt) is a leading German research university, where I studied my second year of my engineering masters degree. 

In addition to my coursework and working on my master thesis industrial project, I was eager to learn more so I decided to help two field experts in the Material Modelling Department. There, I  developed a finite element model using COMSOL Multiphysics to model power (AC) losses in macroscopic superconductor hybrid structures. Through effective time management, problem solving and team work skills, my results were published in the Journal of Applied Physics.
profile_positions.title: Modelling Engineer - Student Position

profile_positions.description:
Fraunhofer Institute of Chemical Technology (ICT) is a German organization that develops technology for defense and security, air and space travel, automotive and transport industry, chemistry and process engineering, and energy and environment.

I conducted a four month industrial internship at Fraunhofer ICT as a component of my first year masters degree. My role as a design engineer was to optimize performance of high-temperature proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells. I successfully optimized the concentration of the ethanol fuel which resulted in an 10% increased energy conversion efficiency. Moreover, I implemented cost-saving initiatives to use more efficient and less expensive materials in the design.

I used elechrochemical characterization tools like electrochemical mass spectrometry, cyclic voltammetry, and chronoamperometry to gather data, of which I analyzed with OriginPro and Microsoft Excel.
profile_positions.title: Fuel Cell Design Engineer - Industrial Internship

profile_positions.description:
The Centre for Advanced Materials Joining (CAMJ) is a mechanical engineering centre at the University of Waterloo which specialized in developing technology related to welding, joining, and industrially-supported applications.

I worked there as a student assistant while attending the University of Waterloo in addition to my course work and projects during my last year of undergraduate studies. As a research engineer, I studied new technology (semiconductor nanowires) for effectively treating wastewater from dyes and pharmaceuticals. I conducted scientific research and developed experimental design and process for large scale cleaning of wastewater. I utilized UV-vis spectroscopy and XRD to gather data.

My results and work were published in two scientific articles communicating the technology in the Waste and Biomass Valorization Journal (2012) and in the Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology (2013).
profile_positions.title: Wastewater Treatment Research Engineer - Student Position

company.name: Cambridge University Science and Policy Exchange

volunteer_experiences.description:
I founded the TUD Think Tank club at Technische Universität Darmstadt that promotes innovation and brain storming for solving complex problems.

During the meetings we discussed social initiatives, entrepreneurship principles, and the current energy landscape. In addition, trips in Europe were organized to hone our foreign language skills (for me French and German), to take in a new culture, and to learn some history.

volunteer_experiences.role: Grenoble INP PHELMA Basketball Varsity (Division 1) Team
volunteer_experiences.description: During my first year of my Masters degree studies, I also played for Division 1, Grenoble INP PHELMA varsity basketball team. We made it to the final eight tournament, which was held at Besançon in France. We took home the bronze medal.

company.name: United for Literacy formerly Frontier College

volunteer_experiences.description:
During my undergraduate degree studies I volunteered with Frontier College at two clubs on a weekly basis:

1. St. David’s Homework Club - I tutored students with specific homework problems, with the aim to improve literacy and help them achieve their academic goals.

2. Waterloo Public Library - I built a learning foundation in students of ages 6-10 and promoted continuous learn through literacy games and one on one reading sessions.
